t: Job 39
God Speaks of Nature and Its Beings
“Do*pn you know the time the mountain goats give birth? Do*ln you observe the calving of the deer?
Can*ln you count the months they fulfill, Or*ln do you know the time they give birth?
They*ln kneel down, they bring forth their young, They*ln get rid of their labor pains.
Their*ln offspring become strong, they grow up in the open field; They*ln leave and do not return to them.
“Who*ln sent out the wild donkey free? And*ln who loosed the bonds of the swift donkey,
To*ln whom I gave the wilderness for a home And*ln the salt land for his dwelling place?
He*ln scorns the tumult of the city, The*ln shoutings of the driver he does not hear.
He*ln explores the mountains for his pasture And*ln searches after every green thing.
Will*ln the wild ox consent to serve you, Or*ln will he spend the night at your manger?
Can*ln you bind the wild ox in a furrow with ropes, Or*ln will he harrow the valleys after you?
Will*ln you trust him because his strength is great And*ln leave your labor to him?
Will*ln you have faith in him that he will return your grain And*ln gather it*i from*i your threshing floor?
“The*ln ostriches’ wings flap joyously With*ln the pinion and plumage of love,
For*ln she abandons her eggs to the earth And*ln warms them in the dust,
And*ln she forgets that a foot may crush them, Or*ln that a wild beast may trample them.
She*ln treats her young cruelly, as if they*i were not hers; Though*ln her labor be in vain, she*i is unconcerned;
Because*ln God has made her forget wisdom, And*ln has not given her a share of understanding.
When*ln she lifts herself on high, She*ln laughs at the horse and his rider.
“Do*ln you give the horse his*i might? Do*ln you clothe his neck with a mane?
Do*ln you make him leap like the locust? His*ln majestic snorting is terrible.
He*ln paws in the valley, and rejoices in his*i strength; He*ln goes out to meet the weapons.
He*ln laughs at fear and is not dismayed; And*ln he does not turn back from the sword.
The*ln quiver rattles against him, The*ln flashing spear and javelin.
With*ln shaking and rage he races over the ground, And*ln he does not stand still at the voice of the trumpet.
As*ln often as the trumpet sounds*i he says, ‘Aha!’ And*ln he scents the battle from afar, And*ln the thunder of the captains and the war cry.
“Is*ln it by your understanding that the hawk soars, Stretching*ln his wings toward the south?
Is*ln it at your command that the eagle mounts up And*ln makes his nest on high?
On*ln the cliff he dwells and lodges, Upon*ln the rocky crag, an inaccessible place.
From*ln there he spies out food; His*ln eyes see it*i from afar.
His*ln young ones also suck up blood; And*ln where the slain are, there is he.”
